abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project was
            satisfactory. The relevance of the project's policy
            measures are reflected by subsequent structural adjustments
            loans (SAL), which further strengthen the reform program.
            Both performances, the Bank and Borrower's, are
            reviewed in terms of what reasonably transpired as a result
            of the financial crisis, and what would have been a better
            course in retrospect. Similarly, the lessons learned are
            reviewed within that context, suggesting that both the Bank,
            and Korean authorities should have maintained closer ties,
            to better anticipate the events leading to the crisis.
            Although the Bank customized the operation to meet the
            urgency of the situation, earlier involvement in discussions
            with the Government, and the International Monetary Fund
            (IMF), should have taken place. The potential to maximize
            negotiation results, once stabilization measures are
            established, could be emphasized to achieve reforms;
            however, any additional conditionality should be taken into
            consideration, for the program's effectiveness could be
            well in danger. The Bank should have the capacity for
            management portfolio risk, to assess risk adjustment capital
            allocation. However, careful consistency with the
            Bank's business, i.e., development institution, should
            be maintained; hence, a subsequent policy specifies this
            concern, in the form of special SALs.
